title: Rain on harvested grain
vignette: Bundles left in the field get soaked by a sudden storm before threshing.

options.text: The moisture prepares them to receive impurity.
Since the owner didn't want the rain, it doesn't count.

title: Juice seepage during transport
vignette: Grapes leak slightly while being carried to the winery.

options.text: Leaked juice renders the grapes susceptible to impurity.
Minor seepage ignored; only deliberate wetting matters.

title: Dew collected before sunrise
vignette: Early morning workers gather cucumbers still covered in heavy dew.

options.text: Dew qualifies as water that readies them for impurity.
Natural dew is insignificant unless intentionally spread.

title: Washing fruits for market
vignette: The vendor rinses apples to make them shine before selling.

options.text: Since he desired the moisture, they are now susceptible.
Washing is purely cosmetic and has no halakhic effect.

title: Contact with sweat
vignette: A worker's perspiration drips onto figs as he packages them.

options.text: Human sweat counts among the liquids that enable impurity.
Sweat is not one of the seven liquids; it has no effect.

title: Spilled wine on produce
vignette: While setting aside tithed wine, some splashes onto nearby wheat.

options.text: Wine willingly spilled qualifies the wheat for impurity.
Since it was accidental, the wheat remains unaffected.

title: Honey glaze after baking
vignette: Honey is brushed onto hot loaves once they come from the oven.

options.text: Because he wants the honey, the loaves can now receive impurity.
Only liquids applied before baking count, not after.

title: Fruit stored in damp cellar
vignette: Moisture condenses on pears kept in a cool underground room.

options.text: Condensation counts as unwanted wetting and is ignored.
Any moisture, even unintended, makes them susceptible.

title: Blood from slaughter
vignette: Drops of animal blood fall on vegetables near the butcher table.

options.text: Blood is one of the liquids that confer susceptibility.
Only if the owner wanted it there; accidental drops don't count.

title: Using oil for preservation
vignette: Olive oil is rubbed on cheese wheels to keep them from drying out.

options.text: The oil counts since the owner intends it, enabling impurity.
Preservative oil isn't considered a liquid for these laws.

title: Rainwater after threshing
vignette: Grain already piled in the barn gets wet from a leaky roof.

options.text: Since he doesn't want the leak, the grain stays unsuited for impurity.
Any wetting, wanted or not, prepares it for impurity.

title: Liquid from crushed fruit
vignette: Juice seeps out when heavy sacks of plums are stacked.

options.text: Unwanted leakage does not create susceptibility.
If the owner plans to extract juice later, it does count.

title: Wetting by immersion
vignette: A batch of olives accidentally falls into the mikveh during cleaning.

options.text: Since he didn't want them wet, they're unaffected.
Any immersion in water prepares them for impurity regardless.

title: Watered by livestock
vignette: Cattle drink from a trough and splash water onto nearby hay.

options.text: Animal-caused wetting was not desired and has no effect.
Even unintended livestock splashes enable impurity.

title: Drying produce after rain
vignette: Sun quickly dries vegetables that were soaked earlier that morning.

options.text: Once dry, they are still susceptible since they were wet willingly.
Drying resets them; they no longer receive impurity.
